choices.C: Syslog logging is disabled by default.
choices.E: Messages are stored in the internal memory of the device.
choices.D: Messages can be erased when the device reboots.
choices.B: The size of the log file is dependent on the resources of the device.
choices.A: Messages are stored external to the device.

discussion.content:
"Storage size does depend on the available disk space of the external syslog server", not on the device (i.e. the router).

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-documents/how-to-configure-logging-in-cisco-ios/ta-p/3132434

Syslog Server logging:

You want to send log messages to a remote syslog server. By using this we can send messages to an external device for storing this logs and the storage size does depend on the available disk space of the external syslog server. This option is not enabled by default.

The answer should be A and C.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-documents/how-to-configure-logging-in-cisco-ios/ta-p/3132434

questions.question_text: Which two statements about syslog logging are true? (Choose two.)
For which two reasons was RFC 1918 address space define? (Choose two)

discussion.content:
The answer should be A and D. 

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1918

Motivation: 

 With the proliferation of TCP/IP technology worldwide, including
 outside the Internet itself, an increasing number of non-connected
 enterprises use this technology and its addressing capabilities for
 sole intra-enterprise communications, without any intention to over directly connect to other enterprises or the Internet itself. The Internet has grown beyond anyone's expectations. Sustained exponential growth continues to introduce new challenges. One
 challenge is a concern within the community that globally unique
 address space will be exhausted. A separate and far more pressing concern is that the amount of routing overhead will grow beyond the capabilities of Internet Service Providers. Efforts are in progress within the community to find long term solutions to both of these problems. Meanwhile it is necessary to revisit address allocation procedures, and their impact on the Internet routing system.
The answer is A and D. The RFC itself explanins that the motivation was preserve IPv4 addresses and ISP overheading.

choices.B: to reduce the occurrence of overlapping IP addresses
choices.D: reduce the size of ISP routing tables
choices.A: to preserve public IPv4 address space
choices.C: to preserve public IPv6 address space

questions.question_text: Which two statements about access points are true? (Choose Two)

choices.B: in Most cases, they are physically connected to other network devices to provide network connectivity.
choices.D: Most access points provide Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity.
choices.C: They can protect a network from internal and external threats.
choices.A: They can provide access within enterprises and to the public.
choices.E: They must be hardwired to a modem.

discussion.content: It should be A and B

choices.D: Dynamic route learned from the server.
choices.B: A route used when a destination route is missing.
choices.C: A route to the exact /32 destination address
choices.A: A route that is manually configured

discussion.content: The answer is C. That is the route to ONE host address which has a /32 subnet mask.

questions.question_text: Which definition of a host route is true?

discussion.content: D. 239.255.0.1 is a multicast IP address, which allows sending a message to multiple devices across different subnets.

questions.answer_description:
Multicast is a networking protocol where one host can send a message to a special multicast IP address and one or more network devices can listen for and receive those messages.
Multicast works by taking advantage of the existing IPv4 networking infrastructure, and it does so in something of a weird fashion. As you read, keep in mind that things are a little confusing because multicast was "shoe-horned" in to an existing technology. For the rest of this article, let's use the multicast IP address of
239.255.0.1.
questions.question_text: Which destination IP address can a host use to send one message to multiple devices across different subnets?
